video.title: Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Hey, subscribed to the Patreon yet? There's  all kinds of incentives. Exclusive access.
If you get a booboo we all have to come around  your house and give it kisses. And then there's
the getting to vote for what classic game I have  to review when the Summer doldrums roll around,
which is basically as good as getting to decide  what I have to wear instead of underpants for a
week. Last time Chrono Trigger won out, but  on this occasion the weebs were defeated by
the tedious semi-skimmed milk drinking terminally  mainstream-brained and we're stuck with a fucking
Star Wars title. Knights of the Old Republic,  the classic Bioware RPG, which I'd never played,
but understood to essentially be Bioware's  prototype for Mass Effect. And what a relief it
must have been to shift to their own IP. Imagine  the poor bastards on Bioware's writing team,
all keen to apply their characteristic complicated  storytelling and nuanced moral choices, when they
were first told they had to work with the fucking  Star Wars universe. "There's two opposing groups,
right, one side are space monks  dedicated to peace and justice,
and the other are genocidal murderers who dress  up in black robes and skull masks and all have
names like Bumplete Castard. Now, write a  story about that with some subtlety to it."
So with that in mind, perhaps I shouldn't have  been surprised that every single fucking choice
in this choices matter RPG boils down to "Oh no  I must save the baby lambs and kiss all their
booboos," "I'm bored of looking at your face so  now you die," or "Can we please change the fucking
subject." So if you're asking how Knights of the  Old Republic holds up, not terribly well so far,
at least from the completely non-nostalgia  blinded viewpoint. Well, having said that,
at the very start when the dude bursts into our  cabin and goes "The ship's under attack! We've
got to escape! Press the A button to put on your  socks!" I did have a little nostalgic quiver. Ooh,
I remember when integrated tutorials fucking  sucked. So 2003's pretty fucking old and creaky
now. I had to go to the PC Gaming Wiki to get  the game set up properly, and I hate having to
go there, I always leave smelling of Cheeto  dust. Even then there were endless glitches:
dialogue would sometimes start skipping  without my consent, movement controls kept
locking after combat so I had to constantly save  and reload, but I can't hold it against the game.
It was a miracle there was still a version  on Steam I could buy, and a double miracle
that it fucking worked at all, I don't want  to push my luck and demand the third miracle
of complete stability. Still, there were other  technical issues I'm not willing to put down to
age. Like being prevented from leaving areas  because - altogether now - "You must gather
your party before venturing forth!" Said party  being three rooms back struggling to outwit a
slightly askew floor tile. And of course this is  relatively early 3D graphics so everything looks
like cardboard dog puke under cheap fluorescent  lighting. The classic Bioware Face problem of
awkwardly delivered dialogue is at its most  Bioware-y when the characters literally have no
means to express their feelings besides dialogue.  Which they can only deliver while standing around
nodding their potato-y, fixed-expression heads  at each other. "I am extremely impressed by your
combat prowess, captain. I know you can't tell  that from my blank, dead eyes but rest assured
pints of hot ladyfoam are currently irrigating  the seven polygons of my inner thighs." Is this
fair? Absolutely not. But once a game goes past  a certain age you lose so many of the quality of
life improvements we've gotten used to that the  question of if it holds up kinda becomes moot.
No, it doesn't, obviously. The environments  are small, dull and sparsely populated and
the interface is a pile of sith. There's no real  sorting of inventory, so if you pick up a document
and want to read it you have to plough through  piles of random equipment you don't want to sell
in case a party member can use it, healing items  that ceased to have any use after every Jedi in
the party got the cure spell, and all those combat  boosters that I'm keeping in case of a difficult
fight and will no doubt be peeling off the back  of my crisper drawer in about six months. Oh yeah,
the combat, that's a steaming pile of sith, too.  The concept of pausing the game and queueing up
your actions is theoretically viable, although  I still hate anything that tries to bridge the
gap between turn based and real time like Jean  Claude Van Damme trying to give himself a hernia,
but in practice it tends to boil down to  everyone standing in a ring taking it in
turns to do an attack while the recipient very  emphatically doesn't react. Where you would
like your character to stand as they attempt  their attacks seems to be a matter of supreme
indifference to the game, and whether or  not hits land is based on random rolls.
So if you lose a fight your best course  of action is to load a save and do exactly
the same thing again but hope RNGesus has  better plans for you. Oh, and whether or
not you finish a fight in good enough shape  to immediately start another is a matter of
supreme indifference to your party members, who  will bolt after the next nearest group of as yet
unalerted enemies like Leroy Jenkins seeing a  deer on his lawn. There's the option to sneak,
but it's 99% useless because it just means  you'll be underlevelled for mandatory fights,
oh, and I hope you didn't spend the first  planet speccing as a ranged combat user
'cos after that the plot forces you to become  a Jedi and then it's light sabers up the bum
for the remainder of the game. So most of the  gameplay sucks Sith, but I kinda suspect it's
the story that's the part most people are  actually nostalgic for, so let's get back
to that. Early on I couldn't stop thinking that  the plot was beat-for-beat identical to A New
Hope. Evil Empire attacks a Republic vessel, the  thing they're after escapes to a nearby planet,
protagonist has to evade the villains by  teaming up with a Jedi, a space captain
and a sentient giant furry hot water bottle  cover, learns to be a Jedi themselves, etc etc.
Maybe that's reaching a bit but there's also  the Empire Strikes Back-style identity twist.
And I should probably have mentioned before  the vote that I already knew the twist thanks
to online cultural osmosis, so I can't speak to  its effectiveness. It is a fun little character
dynamic curveball and I liked how you find  out about it some ways before the end so
you can spend a few missions leaning into it  for giggles, but the more I think about it,
the more questions I want to yell at the screen.  I won't spoil it, but for the sake of discussion
I'll do what I did for Twelve Minutes and swap  it for something equivalent. It turns out that a
major character has had their memory wiped and  all along was secretly Gary Glitter. And he's
having flashbacks every time he hears snatches  of Rock & Roll Part Two. My question is why,
when the dude returns to the Jedi temple,  instead of trying to stop them remembering
their former self, the Jedi council all like "Hey,  you seem like you'd be good at playing glam rock,
here's a sparkly guitar and some platform  shoes." Actually, more pertinent question,
why did they make him think he was a soldier and  send him out into the galaxy in the first place,
rather than make him think he's,  say, the Jedi temple toilet cleaner,
so they can keep an eye on him and make sure  he doesn't get within fifty metres of a school?
